articles.headline: Slow Payers Hinder Trade in Europe
articles.snippet: Legal and language differences hamper debt recovery across borders, posing a deterrent to commerce and economic growth.
articles.abstract: Legal and language differences hamper debt recovery across borders, posing a deterrent to commerce and economic growth.
articles.lead_paragraph: ZARAGOZA, SPAIN — In 2001, an agricultural co-op here was supplying truckloads of wheat to an Italian pasta maker. At first, no one at the Spanish co-op, Arento, was much alarmed when the pasta factory in Milan fell behind in its payments.
articles.byline: By Suzanne Daley and Stephen Castle

articles.headline: Expectations Grow for Greek Debt Restructuring
articles.snippet: An emerging view in Europe is that a permanent solution to Greece’s debt problem will require investors to take losses in a restructuring.
articles.abstract: An emerging view in Europe is that a permanent solution to Greece’s debt problem will require investors to take losses in a restructuring.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Greeks reject a debt restructuring out of hand. The European Central Bank fears that such a move will spread financial panic. And, meanwhile, the European Union and the International Monetary Fund insist that their recipe of bailouts combined with sharp spending cuts makes restructurings unnecessary.

articles.headline: The Assembly Line Is Rolling Again, Tenuously, at Honda in Japan
articles.snippet: Auto production in Japan is at only half the normal level for Honda — as it is for Honda’s bigger rivals, Toyota and Nissan.
articles.abstract: Auto production in Japan is at only half the normal level for Honda — as it is for Honda’s bigger rivals, Toyota and Nissan.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAYAMA, Japan — As an electric sign tallied the vehicles rolling off the Honda assembly line here, a scrolling message exhorted employees: “Let’s pool our strength to overcome this crisis.”

articles.headline: Robert Mugabe Hounds Rivals in Zimbabwe, Parties Say
articles.snippet: President Robert Mugabe and his party are engaged in a campaign of intimidation and harassment intended to drive his opponents out of office.
articles.abstract: President Robert Mugabe and his party are engaged in a campaign of intimidation and harassment intended to drive his opponents out of office.
articles.lead_paragraph: HARARE, Zimbabwe — More than a quarter of President Robert Mugabe’s opponents in Parliament have been arrested since agreeing to join the government in a shaky power-sharing arrangement, part of an intensifying campaign of harassment intended to drive them out of office, officials from both sides say.

articles.headline: Many Hit by Spill Now Feel Caught in Claim Process
articles.snippet: Tens of thousands of Gulf Coast residents, frustrated by the process of submitting claims to BP after the 2010 oil spill, have actively sought legal help to cover loss of income or property damage.
articles.abstract: Tens of thousands of Gulf Coast residents, frustrated by the process of submitting claims to BP after the 2010 oil spill, have actively sought legal help to cover loss of income or property damage.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAYOU LA BATRE, Ala. — By October, Tim Nguyen found that his work in a Mississippi shipyard was no longer paying the bills. His hours had been cut back, part of the general ebb of work along the Gulf Coast after the terrible summer of BP.
articles.byline: By Campbell Robertson and John Schwartz

articles.headline: Luck Spares Some From Deadly Tornado Swarm
articles.snippet: Despite death and devastation in a corner of North Carolina, a sense of marvel that a mile-wide tornado didn’t do worse.
articles.abstract: Despite death and devastation in a corner of North Carolina, a sense of marvel that a mile-wide tornado didn’t do worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: ASKEWVILLE, N.C. — For all the deaths and broken bones and flattened houses, there were still some miracles packed into the 10 minutes it took for the last of a great roar of tornadoes to chew through this rural corner of the state.

articles.headline: In This Fairy Tale, Not One, but Two Queens in Waiting
articles.snippet: At Britain’s royal wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton, one of the most uneasy seats in the church may be the one occupied by Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall.
articles.abstract: At Britain’s royal wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton, one of the most uneasy seats in the church may be the one occupied by Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — When 1,900 invited guests take their coveted places in Westminster Abbey next week for the wedding of Prince William and Kate Middleton, one of the most uneasy seats in the 13th-century Gothic church may be the one occupied by Camilla, Duchess of Cornwall, the longtime lover of Prince Charles, and since her marriage to the heir to the throne in 2005, the stepmother to William, Charles’s older son.

articles.headline: Even on Religious Campuses, Students Fight for Gay Identity
articles.snippet: Decades after the gay rights movement swept secular schools, more gays and lesbians are coming out at Christian colleges but are running up against conservative administrators, trustees and alumni.
articles.abstract: Decades after the gay rights movement swept secular schools, more gays and lesbians are coming out at Christian colleges but are running up against conservative administrators, trustees and alumni.
articles.lead_paragraph: WACO, Tex. — Battles for acceptance by gay and lesbian students have erupted in the places that expect it the least: the scores of Bible colleges and evangelical Christian universities that, in their founding beliefs, see homosexuality as a sin.

articles.headline: Syria Steps Up Its Crackdown While Promising Reform
articles.snippet: Syria tried to placate protesters with pledges of sweeping reform hours after forces crushed one of the biggest gatherings yet.
articles.abstract: Syria tried to placate protesters with pledges of sweeping reform hours after forces crushed one of the biggest gatherings yet.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The Syrian government tried to placate protesters with declarations of sweeping reform on Tuesday while also issuing harsh threats of reprisals if demonstrations did not come to an end, as one of the Arab world’s most repressive countries struggled to blunt the most serious challenge to the 40-year rule of the Assad family.
